item.title: Hellblade 2 Lands On PS5 In August With An Enhanced Edition
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Senua's Saga: Hellblade 2 will officially arrive on PS5 on August 12 as part of an Enhanced edition release. This new version of the game will also be available as a free update for Xbox Series X|S and PC versions, and it includes various graphical and gameplay additions, an enhanced photo mode, and developer commentary.

Microsoft says that the Enhanced Edition includes a performance mode that targets a frame rate of 60fps, and on PC specifically, users can push the game's graphics with a "Very High" preset. The game will also be Steam Deck Verified once the Enhanced Edition launches.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Senuaâ€™s Saga: Hellblade II Playstation 5 Official Trailer

PS5 owners looking to experience the full story can grab a deluxe edition of Hellblade 2 for $70, which includes Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice optimized for the console and its original soundtrack. If you already own the PS4 version, you can upgrade to the PS5 edition for free.

For the new features, players can once again take on the malicious Dark Rot in an additional challenge mode, and in the upgraded photo mode, several improvements have been made and an all-new "Motion" tab for custom cinematic video capture has been added.

The commentary tracks from the developers also sound interesting, as there's over four hours of audio from the game's cast, the Ninja Theory team, and people who helped the team to respectfully convey Senua's experience of psychosis. It's not known if studio founder Tameem Antoniades is included, as he is no longer with the company.

Microsoft has had many successful releases on PS5 lately, as several of the best-selling games for April 2025 on PlayStation in the US were all published by the company. Forza Horizon 5 and Indiana Jones and the Great Circle have been big winners on Sony's platform, and Hellblade 2 won't be the only game arriving in August.

It'll be joined by Gears of War Reloaded--which launches on August 26--and the game will support cross-play and cross-progression on all platforms that it launches for.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Death Stranding 2 Was Made In Partnership With A Nintendo-Owned Studio
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The CG animation and motion capture company Nintendo Pictures, formerly known as Dynamo Pictures, has been revealed to have worked on Sony's Death Stranding 2: On the Beach.

VGC spotted the company's name in the Death Stranding 2 credits. While it might seem surprising to see a Nintendo-owned company work on a PlayStation game, it's not totally unexpected. Prior to Nintendo's acquisition of Dynamo in 2022 and re-branding to Nintendo Pictures, the company worked on the original Death Stranding.

Since 2022, Nintendo Pictures' work on game projects has focused on Nintendo games, including Super Mario Bros. Wonder and The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom. But it's possible the work Nintendo Pictures did on Death Stranding 2 was done prior to Nintendo's buyout, or that a previous contract was in place to allow the company to work on Death Stranding 2 even as a company owned by Nintendo.

Another theory is that Nintendo Pictures' work beyond games is allowed to go forward for animation projects. After all, Nintendo Pictures did work for the Pretty Cure anime from Toei Animation following Nintendo's buyout of the company.

In any event, this isn't the first time Sony and Nintendo will work together, as the two companies are partnered up for the live-action The Legend of Zelda movie. Sony Pictures and Nintendo are co-financing the movie, which was recently delayed a bit.

As for Death Stranding 2, it's available now for people who pay more, while the standard edition unlocks on June 26. GameSpot's Death Stranding 2 review scored the game a 7/10. Reviewer Diego NicolÃ¡s ArgÃ¼ello wrote, "Death Stranding 2: On The Beach is fixated on revisiting past ideas, which limits its impact to being a good but not great sequel."

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/death-stranding-2-was-made-in-partnership-with-a-nintendo-owned-studio/1100-6532704/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: Kindle Fire HD 8 Plus Tablet Is Over 50% Off Ahead Of Prime Day 2025
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Prime Day is quickly approaching, but if youâ€™re in the market for an affordable tablet, thereâ€™s no need to wait until July 8. Amazon is currently dropping the price of its Amazon Fire HD 8 Plus (32GB) to just $55 (was $120)--bringing it to the lowest price weâ€™ve ever seen. Thereâ€™s also an excellent deal for the 64GB model, and you can snag a preowned Amazon Fire HD 10 for just $70 (was $120). All three are limited-time deals, though itâ€™s unclear when theyâ€™ll disappear.

2022 Amazon Fire HD 8 Plus

32GB: $55 (was $120) | 64GB: $85 (was $150)

While these arenâ€™t the latest models of the tablet, theyâ€™re still powerful enough for all your daily computing needs, such as browsing the web or streaming TV shows. Equipped with 3GB RAM, a 2MP front-facing camera, a 5MP rear-facing camera, up to 13 hours of battery life, and a durable 8-inch HD display, itâ€™s a pretty great value at just $55.

If youâ€™re worried about storage space, the 64GB version is on sale for $85. However, both tablets feature a microSD card slot, allowing you to add up to 1 TB of additional storage space.

Available apps include Netflix, Prime Video, Disney+, and Showtime. Google Play is not supported, but youâ€™ll find most of the big apps and games compatible with the Fire HD 8 Plus, so give it a look if you need an affordable tablet that can handle all the basics. Note that this version of the tablet features an ad-supported lockscreen.

For comparison, the newest Amazon Fire HD 8 starts at $100.

Amazon Fire HD 10 (Preowned)

$70 (was $120)

Want something with a larger display? A preowned, like-new version of the Fire HD 10 is on sale for $70 (was $120). Along with a 10.1-inch 1080p screen, it gets you a 5MP rear-facing camera, a 5MP front-facing camera, a microSD card slot, 3GB RAM, and the same 13-hour battery life of the Fire HD 8 Plus. It also features an ad-supported lock screen.

Although itâ€™s preowned, Amazon tests each device to ensure its functionality and quality. Amazon's refurbishment process includes secure data wipes and replacement of faulty hardware, so it should feel like a brand-new tablet.

These tablets arenâ€™t the only great Amazon products on sale ahead of Prime Day. A long list of Amazon Fire 4K TVs and soundbars are seeing nice discounts right now--giving you a cheap way to upgrade your home theater. Thereâ€™s also a fantastic limited-time deal on the Amazon Fire TV Stick 4K, as itâ€™s just $25 (was $50). For more great deals, swing by our Prime Day Hub--and be sure to sign up for Prime so you can cash in on all the offers when Prime Day begins on July 8.

item.title: Samsung Already Has Early Prime Day Deals On TVs, Soundbars, And More
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Samsung is offering a bunch of impressive price cuts ahead of Prime Day, with TVs, soundbars, and memory products all seeing significant discounts. The most enticing deals are for TVs, as you can save well over $2,000 on select products--making this an excellent time to upgrade your home theater. Weâ€™ve noticed some of the deals are already selling out (The Frame QLED TV 50-Inch is no longer available in all regions), so weâ€™d recommend checking out all the offers while you can. Amazon is also price-matching some of the offers, so give it a look if you notice models out of stock at Samsung.

The Frame TV

Save up to $1,300

Pulling double duty as a television set and picture frame, The Frame TV is a versatile 4K QLED display. Its Quantum Processor 4K helps produce impressive 4K HDR visuals, while a 120Hz refresh rate makes it pretty great as a traditional TV. Itâ€™s available in seven sizes, six of which are currently on sale.

  • 43-Inch -- $750 ($1,000)
  • 50-Inch -- $850 ($1,300)
  • 55-Inch -- $1,000 ($1,500)
  • 65-Inch -- $1,500 ($2,000)
  • 75-Inch -- $2,000 ($3,000)
  • 85-Inch -- $3,000 ($4,300)

Neo QLED TVs (4K and 8K)

Save up to $2,700

Three different lineups of Neo QLED TVs are on sale -- the QN90D, the QN800D, and the QN900D. The QN90D is the most budget-friendly model, with prices starting at $900 for the 43-inch version (was $1,500). Featuring Mini LEDs, a 4K resolution, support for Dolby Atmos, and up to 144Hz refresh rates, itâ€™s a solid option at this new low price.

Step up to the QN800D, and youâ€™ll get an impressive 8K resolution--and 8K AI upscaling, so most programs will benefit from its brilliant display. This lineup is much more expensive, though itâ€™s currently on sale. The cheapest model is the 65-inch, which is now $3,000 (was $3,500).

Before you pull the trigger on the QN800D, be sure to check out the QN900D--its successor. The 65-inch model is the same price as the older QN800D, making it the better choice among the two, as it comes with an upgraded processor for faster performance.

Amazon is price-matching several QN90D, QN800D, and QN900D products.

Samsung OLED TVs

Save up to $2,100

Both the S90D and S95D lineups are on sale at Samsung. Both are remarkably similar, offering 144Hz refresh rates, 4K resolutions, and the NQ4 AI Gen2 processor. The main difference is the display--the S90D features a glossy screen, whereas the S95D gets you a matte screen. The matte screen helps eliminate glare, though some users note it doesnâ€™t look quite as vibrant as the S90D.

The S90D is also available in sizes from 42 inches to 83 inches, while the S95D is only available in three sizes (55, 65, and 77 inches). However, both products are incredibly popular and have earned high marks from buyers, and now that you can save up to $2,100, theyâ€™re an excellent choice for your game room.

The S95D (65-Inch) is on sale for $2,400 (was $3,400), while the S90D (65-Inch) is just $1,300 (was $2,700). Be sure to check out the full lineup, as youâ€™ll save more cash on the larger displays.

Amazon is price-matching most products in the S95D and S90D lineups.

Samsung QLED 4K TVs

Save up to $1,000

The QLED 4K Q80D and Q70D lineups comprise several products, although most are currently sold out. However, you can still find the Class QLED 4K Q80D (75-Inch) for just $1,200 (was $2,200). Along with the same NQ4 AI Gen2 processor found in the OLED TVs above, it gets you 4K AI upscaling, up to 120Hz refresh rate, and support for Dolby Atmos.

The Class QLED 4K Q70D, meanwhile, is a bit more affordable. The 75-Inch model is just $800 (was $1,800), and it shares many of the same specs as its more expensive sibling--including 120Hz refresh rates, 4K AI upscaling, and the NQ4 AI Gen 2 processor. However, most viewers will find the Q80D to offer better overall picture quality, thanks to improved HDR and a local dimming feature.

Amazon is price-matching most products in the Q80D lineup.

Samsung Q-Series Soundbar HW-QS700F

$600 (was $700)

This 3.1.2 Channel soundbar comes with a wireless subwoofer, which should bring all your explosive video games and movies to life. Dolby Atmos support is a big selling point of the soundbar, and using Samsungâ€™s SpaceFit Sound Pro technology, the device can automatically calibrate itself to your room. It also supports Google Home, Google Cast, Apple AirPlay, and Spotify.

Memory Products

Save up to $120

While these price cuts arenâ€™t quite as exciting as the ones above, theyâ€™re still worth a closer look. The Samsung Portable SSD T9 (1TB) is on sale for $130 (was $140). However, the massive 4TB version is down to just $320 (was $440). Regardless of capacity, the SSD offers speeds of up to 2,000 MB/s and a durable design thatâ€™s rated for drops of nearly 10 feet. If you need to expand storage on your PC or PS5, the 9100 Pro (1TB) is on sale for $170 (was $200).
